title: Chemical Bonding - Ionic and Covalent
explanation: Understanding how atoms combine through ionic and covalent bonds, including bond formation, properties, and molecular structures.
detailedNotes:
Chemical bonds form when atoms share or transfer electrons to achieve stable electron configurations.

IONIC BONDING:
- Transfer of electrons from metal to non-metal
- Forms positive ions (cations) and negative ions (anions)
- Held together by electrostatic attraction
- Example: NaCl (sodium transfers electron to chlorine)

Properties of Ionic Compounds:
- High melting and boiling points
- Conduct electricity when molten or dissolved (ions mobile)
- Hard but brittle crystals
- Soluble in water (polar solvent)

COVALENT BONDING:
- Sharing of electrons between non-metals
- Forms molecules
- Electrons shared to fill outer shells
- Types:
  • Single bond: 1 pair shared (H-H)
  • Double bond: 2 pairs shared (O=O)
  • Triple bond: 3 pairs shared (N≡N)

Properties of Covalent Compounds:
- Lower melting and boiling points
- Don't conduct electricity (no free ions)
- Can be gases, liquids, or soft solids
- Soluble in non-polar solvents

ELECTRONEGATIVITY:
- Determines bond type
- Large difference → ionic bond
- Small difference → covalent bond
- Equal electronegativity → pure covalent (non-polar)

POLAR COVALENT BONDS:
- Unequal sharing of electrons
- Creates partial charges (δ+ and δ-)
- Example: H₂O (oxygen more electronegative than hydrogen)

LEWIS DOT STRUCTURES:
- Diagram showing valence electrons
- Dots represent electrons
- Shows bonding and lone pairs

OCTET RULE:
- Atoms tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to achieve 8 valence electrons
- Exceptions: hydrogen (wants 2), elements in Period 3+ can exceed octet

examples.title: Ionic Bond Formation
examples.solution:
Sodium (Na) has 1 valence electron, chlorine (Cl) has 7 valence electrons.

1. Sodium donates its 1 electron to chlorine
2. Sodium becomes Na⁺ ion (stable, like neon)
3. Chlorine becomes Cl⁻ ion (stable, like argon)
4. Electrostatic attraction holds Na⁺ and Cl⁻ together
5. Forms ionic compound NaCl

examples.title: Covalent Bond
examples.content: How does a water molecule (H₂O) form?
examples.solution:
Oxygen needs 2 more electrons to complete its octet, each hydrogen needs 1 electron.

1. Oxygen shares one electron with each hydrogen
2. Each hydrogen shares its electron with oxygen
3. Forms two O-H covalent bonds
4. Oxygen has 2 bonding pairs and 2 lone pairs
5. Results in bent molecular shape

exercises.question: Which type of bond is formed between a metal and a non-metal?
exercises.explanation: Ionic bonds form between metals (which lose electrons) and non-metals (which gain electrons).

exercises.question: H₂ molecule contains:
exercises.explanation: Two hydrogen atoms share one pair of electrons, forming a single covalent bond (H-H).

pastQuestions.question: Ionic compounds conduct electricity when:
pastQuestions.explanation: Ionic compounds conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water because ions are free to move and carry charge.
